explanation: Vowels can be short (e.g., 'i' in 'ship' [ɪ]) or long (e.g., 'ee' in 'sheep' [iː]). Long vowels are marked with 'ː'.
A silent 'e' at the end of a word often makes the preceding vowel long. Compare 'mat' [mæt] and 'mate' [meɪt].
The most common sound. It's a weak, unstressed 'uh' sound, found in unstressed syllables like the 'a' in 'about' or 'o' in 'memory'.
When a vowel is followed by an 'r', the 'r' changes the vowel's sound (e.g., 'ar' in 'car' [ɑː], 'or' in 'fork' [ɔː], 'ur' in 'bird' [ɜː]).
In standard British English (RP), the 'r' is typically not pronounced unless it is followed by a vowel sound (e.g., 'car' is [kɑː], but 'car is' is [kɑːr‿ɪz]).
At the start of a stressed syllable, 'p', 't', and 'k' are pronounced with a strong puff of air. Hold your hand to your mouth to feel it.
Place your tongue between your teeth. For [θ] (as in 'thumb'), just blow air. For [ð] (as in 'this'), make a voiced, buzzing sound.
A single sound made at the back of the throat with air flowing through the nose, as in 'king' or 'sing'. Don't pronounce a hard 'g' at the end.
Many words have silent consonants, like the 'b' in 'comb', 'k' in 'knife', 'w' in 'write', or 'l' in 'walk'.
Many consonants come in pairs, where the only difference is the vibration of vocal cords. E.g., /p/ (no voice) vs /b/ (voice), /s/ (no voice) vs /z/ (voice).
'sh' [ʃ] is a hissing sound like in 'shoe'. Its voiced partner [ʒ] is the sound from the 's' in 'treasure' or 'vision'.
'ch' [tʃ] is a 't' followed by 'sh', as in 'church'. Its voiced partner [dʒ] is a 'd' followed by 'zh', as in 'judge'.
In words with more than one syllable, one syllable is stressed more strongly than others. Stress can change the meaning (e.g., 'RE-cord' (noun) vs 're-CORD' (verb)).
In a sentence, content words (nouns, main verbs, adjectives) are typically stressed, while function words (articles, prepositions) are not.
In non-rhotic accents, an 'r' sound is sometimes inserted between two vowel sounds to make them easier to say, e.g., 'law and order' becomes 'law-r-and order'.
